articles.headline: China Is Said to Resume Shipping Rare Earth Minerals
articles.snippet: Officials said that China had eased restrictions on exports of rare earth minerals to the United States and Japan.
articles.abstract: Officials said that China had eased restrictions on exports of rare earth minerals to the United States and Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAOTOU, China  The Chinese government on Thursday abruptly ended its unannounced export embargo on crucial rare earth minerals to the United States, Europe and Japan, four industry officials said.

articles.headline: Panel Says Firms Knew of Cement Flaws Before Spill
articles.snippet: Halliburton knew before the blast on a BP rig in the Gulf of Mexico that the cement mixture was unstable, a commission found.
articles.abstract: Halliburton knew before the blast on a BP rig in the Gulf of Mexico that the cement mixture was unstable, a commission found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Halliburton officials knew weeks before the fatal explosion of the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico that the cement mixture they planned to use to seal the bottom of the well was unstable but still went ahead with the job, the presidential commission investigating the accident said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Verizon Deal Ends Inquiry Over Fees
articles.snippet: The company will pay $25 million to the Treasury and a minimum of $52.8 million in refunds to its customers.
articles.abstract: The company will pay $25 million to the Treasury and a minimum of $52.8 million in refunds to its customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Verizon Wireless, the nation’s largest mobile phone carrier, will pay $25 million to end an investigation into complaints that it had charged 15 million cellphone customers unauthorized data fees over the last three years, the Federal Communications Commission announced Thursday.

articles.headline: Strange Tales in the Land of No Return
articles.snippet: This week some investors bought Treasury bonds for a price that may be higher than the money they will get if they hold the bond to maturity in 2015.
articles.abstract: This week some investors bought Treasury bonds for a price that may be higher than the money they will get if they hold the bond to maturity in 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now the government really is selling bonds that deserve the label “certificates of confiscation.”

articles.headline: Solar Power Projects Face Potential Hurdles
articles.snippet: Without two crucial government programs that reduce investor risk, solar power projects may begin to dry up.
articles.abstract: Without two crucial government programs that reduce investor risk, solar power projects may begin to dry up.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIPTON, Calif.  The long-promised solar building boom in the desert Southwest is finally under way. Here in the Mojave Desert, a dice throw away from the Nevada border, giant road graders and a small army of laborers began turning the dirt for BrightSource Energy’s $2 billion Ivanpah project, the first large-scale solar thermal power plant to be built in the United States in two decades.

articles.headline: Soaring Above India’s Poverty, a 27-Story Home
articles.snippet: The newest building in Mumbai is so over the top that the city’s already elastic boundaries of excess and disparity are being stretched to new dimensions.
articles.abstract: The newest building in Mumbai is so over the top that the city’s already elastic boundaries of excess and disparity are being stretched to new dimensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI  The newest and most exclusive residential tower for this city’s superrich is a cantilevered sheath of steel and glass soaring 27 floors into the sky. The parking garage fills six levels. Three helipads are on the roof. There are terraces upon terraces, airborne swimming pools and hanging gardens in a Blade Runner-meets-Babylon edifice overlooking India’s most dynamic city.

articles.headline: Bernanke’s Reluctance to Speak Out Rankles Some
articles.snippet: The Fed chief Ben Bernanke is far from an outspoken advocate for fiscal policy, unlike his predecessor, Alan Greenspan.
articles.abstract: The Fed chief Ben Bernanke is far from an outspoken advocate for fiscal policy, unlike his predecessor, Alan Greenspan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is all but certain next week to begin a multibillion-dollar effort to coax the recovery along, but privately, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman, worries that more is needed to turn the sluggish economy around and revive employment.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Rejects Qnexa, a Third Weight-Loss Drug
articles.snippet: Federal regulators seem to have heightened their scrutiny of diet pills that could pose risks.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators seem to have heightened their scrutiny of diet pills that could pose risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration rejected another new diet pill on Thursday, the latest setback in the quest to develop treatments for overweight Americans amid the nation’s obesity epidemic.

articles.headline: As Reid Falters, Schumer Subtly Stands in the Wings
articles.snippet: With the majority leader, Harry Reid, in danger of losing his seat, Senators Charles E. Schumer and Richard J. Durbin are maneuvering for the post.
articles.abstract: With the majority leader, Harry Reid, in danger of losing his seat, Senators Charles E. Schumer and Richard J. Durbin are maneuvering for the post.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Charles E. Schumer shipped $500,000 to Nevada in recent weeks to help Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader and Mr. Schumer’s political patron and close friend, as he fights for his political life.
articles.byline: By Raymond Hernandez and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Bill Clinton Urged Florida Democrat to Quit Bid
articles.snippet: The former president urged Kendrick Meek to drop out of the Senate race and endorse Charlie Crist, a Clinton spokesman said.
articles.abstract: The former president urged Kendrick Meek to drop out of the Senate race and endorse Charlie Crist, a Clinton spokesman said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Bill Clinton last week almost succeeded in persuading Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic nominee for the Senate in Florida, to drop out of the three-way race — but Mr. Meek changed his mind at the last minute, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton said Thursday evening.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Debt Fuels Private Equity Revival
articles.snippet: The easy lending environment has created fierce competition for takeover targets, driving up prices.
articles.abstract: The easy lending environment has created fierce competition for takeover targets, driving up prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group demonstrated on Thursday that the private equity industry is thriving amid a weak economy  but they did so in nearly opposing ways.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 2% Rate in Third Quarter
articles.snippet: Friday’s numbers are not likely to provide much of a morale boost for President Obama and Democrats, who are days away from crucial midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Friday’s numbers are not likely to provide much of a morale boost for President Obama and Democrats, who are days away from crucial midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy is a bit like a jetliner short on fuel these days, waiting for something to give it the oomph needed for takeoff.
